text:
Hi <@U0PQ8E25D>
I’m working on implementing a fungible token (similar to ERC-20) and would really appreciate your advice on the best approach. Do you think I should follow CIP-0056 or use Daml.Finance? 
Thanks a lot for your help!
Cc <@U07UEV3B9LP> <@U094KF3PKDY>

elements.text: Hi

text: Good question. You should follow CIP-0056.

elements.text: Good question. You should follow CIP-0056.

text: There's no token reference implementation out there right now. We've been wanting to build one out of splice for quite a while: <https://github.com/hyperledger-labs/splice/milestone/21>

text: Hey folks, how much cc are burned per simple p2p transfer? My understanding is part of it’s dependent on the size of the transfer. is there more to it?

elements.text: Hey folks, how much cc are burned per simple p2p transfer? My understanding is part of it’s dependent on the size of the transfer. is there more to it?

text:
Hi, <@U02AG7A9LKC> Short answer: at current rates, a typical transaction uses up traffic that would have been purchased by burning *about 20 CC*.

For a bit more detail:

Transactions don't actually burn CC; instead someone burns the CC in advance to set up a traffic balance for your node. The traffic balance is denominated in MB.

When you send a transaction it draws down this traffic balance depending on the:
• Size of the transaction (usually the bulk of the traffic)
• Size of all the confirmation messages sent by the counterparties to the transaction (usually a smaller fraction of the traffic but grows with the number of counterparties). 
For a typical peer to peer transaction you're going to draw down  something under 15kB of traffic.

A CC transaction has at least 15 counterparties (your party, your counterparty, plus all 13 SV nodes), and that costs about 15kB. But if you send a private transaction, say moving some Brale SBC onchain, you're only going to have three counterparties (you, the receiver, and Brale), so it's going to cost less; maybe 12 kB or possibly a little under that.

Right now traffic costs $60/MB, which is 1200 CC/MB at current conversion rates.

So the 15kB in traffic used up by a typical transaction would have required a burn of 18 CC when it was created.

When you send a transaction it draws down this traffic balance depending on the:
Size of the transaction (usually the bulk of the traffic)
Size of all the confirmation messages sent by the counterparties to the transaction (usually a smaller fraction of the traffic but grows with the number of counterparties).

For a typical peer to peer transaction you're going to draw down  something under 15kB of traffic.

A CC transaction has at least 15 counterparties (your party, your counterparty, plus all 13 SV nodes), and that costs about 15kB. But if you send a private transaction, say moving some Brale SBC onchain, you're only going to have three counterparties (you, the receiver, and Brale), so it's going to cost less; maybe 12 kB or possibly a little under that.

Right now traffic costs $60/MB, which is 1200 CC/MB at current conversion rates.

So the 15kB in traffic used up by a typical transaction would have required a burn of 18 CC when it was created.

text:
I'm trying to run the console for my localnet node so that I can fetch JWTs for Ledger API requests. I am using the command listed <https://docs.sync.global/app_dev/testing/localnet.html#console|here>:
```IMAGE_TAG=0.4.10 docker compose --env-file $LOCALNET_DIR/compose.env \                                                                                                                      
               --env-file $LOCALNET_DIR/env/common.env \
               -f $LOCALNET_DIR/compose.yaml \
               -f $LOCALNET_DIR/resource-constraints.yaml \
               run --rm console```
But I get:
```/app/entrypoint.sh: line 13: AUTH_APP_PROVIDER_VALIDATOR_USER_NAME: unbound variable```
Am I missing something and/or is there another way to fetch JWTs?

elements.text: I'm trying to run the console for my localnet node so that I can fetch JWTs for Ledger API requests. I am using the command listed
here

IMAGE_TAG=0.4.10 docker compose --env-file $LOCALNET_DIR/compose.env \                                                                                                                      
               --env-file $LOCALNET_DIR/env/common.env \
               -f $LOCALNET_DIR/compose.yaml \
               -f $LOCALNET_DIR/resource-constraints.yaml \
               run --rm console
But I get:
/app/entrypoint.sh: line 13: AUTH_APP_PROVIDER_VALIDATOR_USER_NAME: unbound variable
Am I missing something and/or is there another way to fetch JWTs?

text: for some reason when i submit an exercise command to the command endpoint in json-api, i'm not seeing the exercise result returned in the response even though the openapi suggests I would. It only shows me events like archives and creates. Anyone experience this before and have a solution?

Hello team, I have one more tricky question, why is this contract still returned as active?

The translation was initially erroneous, with an incorrect nonce and most likely occurred at a time when we had no traffic, but the expiration date has long passed, and the contract is still given to the ledger API as active.
Unfortunately, I can’t provide any additional logs, but perhaps you have some thoughts on this matter and/or a recipe for how to archive this contract, because it may be eating up resources in the background.

text: Thanks for raising this. It seems that the expiry automation was not implemented when transfer commands were introduced: <https://github.com/hyperledger-labs/splice/issues/1947>

attachments.fallback: #1947 Add expiry automation for transfer commands
attachments.text: Run it on the provider side which avoids the unavailable participant problems.
attachments.title: #1947 Add expiry automation for transfer commands

elements.text: Thanks for raising this. It seems that the expiry automation was not implemented when transfer commands were introduced:

text: If you'd like to expire it manually just call the `TransferCommand_Expire` choice (<https://github.com/hyperledger-labs/splice/blob/28d17694f42c4b9ff96b6487ab994d43e9879a3c/daml/splice-amulet/daml/Splice/ExternalPartyAmuletRules.daml#L205|code>) directly via the Ledger API using either sender, receiver or delegate party.

elements.text: If you'd like to expire it manually just call the

choice (
code
) directly via the Ledger API using either sender, receiver or delegate party.
